properties.areaDesc: Shannon, MO; Howell, MO; Douglas, MO; Oregon, MO; Texas, MO
properties.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued January 10 at 10:24PM CST until January 11 at 10:30AM CST by NWS Springfield MO
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Springfield has issued a

* Flash Flood Warning for...
Shannon County in south central Missouri...
Eastern Douglas County in southwestern Missouri...
Howell County in south central Missouri...
Texas County in south central Missouri...
Oregon County in south central Missouri...

* Until 1030 AM CST Saturday.

* At 1023 PM CST, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing
heavy rain across the warned area. Up to three inches of rain have
already fallen. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin
shortly.

HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas,
highways, streets and underpasses as well as other
drainage and low lying areas.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
West Plains...                    Echo Bluff State Park...
Current River State Park...       Grand Gulf State Park...
Licking...                        Mountain View...
Thayer...                         Willow Springs...
Cabool...                         Houston...
Winona...                         Alton...
Birch Tree...                     Eminence...
Pomona...                         Summersville...
Raymondville...                   South Fork...
Koshkonong...                     Brandsville...

This warning includes but is not limited to the following low water
crossings...
Route H, 3 miles east of Winona...
Highway 142 at The Spring River west of Lanton...
Highway 142 at The Bennetts River west of Moody...
Route K, 3 miles southwest of Pottersville...
and Route H at Rocky Creek 6 miles northeast of Winona.
properties.instruction:
Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the
dangers of flooding.

CMAMtext: NWS: FLASH FLOOD WARNING this area til 10:30 AM CST. Avoid flooded areas.
